Fields.DialogueText: So here's where you were, Admiral Graf Spee.
... If I may, Kapitän...
Is something wrong?
Just a concern... I understand why you use my full name, and while I cherish it proudly, I also know that Admiral Graf Spee can be a mouthful.
I see.
I'm also concerned about the confusion that could occur if an actual admiral were aboard. To that end... if you called me Graf Spee, I wouldn't mind.

Fields.MenuText: Would Admiral Scheer agree with you, I wonder...
I think the chances of having an actual Admiral on board are too low to worry about that.
If you're worried that much about it...

Fields.DialogueText: My sister shouldn't have a complaint about an informal tradition I establish for my own deck... and her name is shorter.
The chances are low, but not impossible.
You are my captain. The choice is yours.
I guess outside of formal occasions... Graf Spee?
Morganas approaching, Kapitän. The cruiser Malice, by the scent of her.
@BATTLE
That's a well-loved deck of cards you have, Graf Spee.
Thank you, Kapitän. I find playing cards an excellent way of clearing the mind and organizing one's thoughts. Especially when playing alone.
Ah, Solitaire. Or do you prefer to call it "Patience?"
The latter, I think. It's what we've called it back home since 1783.
Learn something new every day.
Are you up for a game of Offiziersskat? I'd be happy to teach you.

Fields.MenuText: That would be lovely, Graf Spee.
Sure, just go easy on me.
Just be warned that I always play to win.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm so glad you feel that way, Kapitän.
Oh, come now, Kapitän. I sincerely doubt you'll need much of a handicap once you learn the rules.
As do I, Kapitän.
It seems I'll have to teach you later, however. Morganas approaching from 40 degrees starboard.
Let's go show them what we're made of!
@BATTLE
May I help you, Kapitän? I hope my prayer time is not an inconvenience.
No, not at all, Graf Spee. I had been wondering where the crucifix on the bulkhead in the back of my mess came from, though. It never occurred to me that it might be yours.
Do you find it strange that I'm Catholic, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Well, a religious ship isn't something you see every day.
I never really thought about it.
Admiral von Spee was Catholic, too, wasn't he?

Fields.DialogueText: There is much we still don't know about each other, Kapitän.
Religion is often a private matter, Kapitän. It is to your credit that you wouldn't concern yourself about such things. Still...
Yes, Kapitän, he was. The Spee line claims many prominent Catholics going back half a millennium at least. I would be delighted to share my copy of the Goldenes Tugendbuch with you.
I for one look forward to coming to understand each other better.
*ALARM*
Merchant distress call to the south. Captain to the bridge.
Morganas can be plenty inconvenient, can't they?
There will be time. Now, however, there is a battle to fight and my main guns are ready to sing on your orders, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Still playing Patience, I see. What other games do you play?
I'm particularly fond of Skat, Kapitän, but it requires three players... and Doppelkopf takes four...
Hmm. Have you by chance ever played poker?
Only once. Fräulein Exeter taught me when we were docked side-by-side. I won. She insisted I cheated and we haven't spoken with each other since.
Did you? Cheat, I mean?
Of course not, Kapitän! I'm merely a quick study.
I guess I shouldn't listen to rumors.
Perhaps not, Kapitän.
Anyway, I'd been thinking of gathering the senior officers for poker nights, Morganas permitting. Would you be interested?
If you think that wise, Kapitän. I'll fight just as seriously in the Messe as I do on the high seas.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, I think they can handle you.
I've lost my shirt to my IO one too many times. Permission granted to avenge me.
No worries there. It's just money, right?

Fields.DialogueText: We'll see, Kapitän.
I'll do my best then, Kapitän.
I suspect the Zahlmeister won't share your insouciance.
Speaking of card games, weren't you going to teach me to play Offiziersskat? Before we were rudely interrupted...
*ALARM*
It seems we will be again, Kapitän.
The Morganas really do know how to ruin an evening, don't they?
@BATTLE
I'm not surprised to see you on deck on a day like today... and helping log weather observations and measurements, too.
This isn't the first time. I like to assist as often as I can.
Oh?
Ja. Weather is not to be taken lightly. Predicting it seems more an art than a science though, even with all the instruments.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you had a better instinct for that. You can sense Morganas, after all.
Reading a gauge is easy. Interpreting the results is the art.
I expect to see you helping out rain or shine.

Fields.DialogueText: You give me too much credit, Kapitän. The ocean is vast, and I can see the future about as well as you can.
Is that so? Then I shall be patient and diligent with my practice.
Absolutely. I wouldn't dream of being a fair-weather assistant.
That said, I know a Morgana storm when I see it.
Natural storms are bad enough...
@BATTLE
Next time I'd appreciate it if you'd leave my officers their skivvies at least. I've never seen anyone press the advantage like you, Graf Spee.
I think I can see why Exeter felt so slighted.
My success was completely within the rules, Kapitän, I assure you! And my takings did not exceed the limit you set for the night.

Fields.MenuText: To within a Reichspfennig.
It took the Zahlmeister's abacus to prove it.
Maybe we need to switch to penny stakes.

Fields.DialogueText: You chose to play in German currency, Kapitän. Can I help it if I'm so adept in calculating my own denominations?
He seemed quite cross with the result, too.
I doubt the Wachsoffizier would appreciate the lack of drama.
I know, I know. It's my own fault for introducing poker. Little did I know that you were a natural with a poker face as hard as your belt armor.
A poker face is entirely within the rules, Kapitän.
That it is, Graf Spee.
Why fight if you don't fight to win, Kapitän?
I'm just glad you're on my side.
I will always be by your side, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
Merchant distress signal to the north. Captain and Scary Poker Face to the bridge.
That... I'll...
Save it for the Morgana, Graf Spee. I really need my senior officers in one piece.
@BATTLE
Ahoy, Schiffsdame. The Kapitän requests your presence at the amidships boathouse when you're done with the airshow and the fish tire of you.
Ja, Kapitän? How can I help you before I go ensure that the Wachsoffizier doesn't shower with hot water for a week?
Oh, Graf Spee, my IO's just sore still from the last poker night. That, and I think there may be just a touch of jealousy over your delightful freedom.
I'm sorry, Kapitän?
You're as graceful as your hull, prancing with the dolphins riding our wake alongside. Not to mention that pirouette as you ghosted through the superstructure to land here.
It's thrilling to watch for anyone with a romantic bone in their body.
Kapitän, I do not "prance". That was simply training, I assure you.
Training?
Of course training, Kapitän. What else could it be? It will help me better assist my seaplanes and weave the ship between Nixen shells.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose the pilots will appreciate it.
Maybe we need to consider how to help them with spotting.
Those pilots of ours are enough of an aerobatics troupe as it is.

Fields.DialogueText: They do, Kapitän. If you ask the Wachsoffizier, we've extended their endurance by 20% since I manifested.
Good idea, Kapitän. I'll start practicing my distance sighting when I'm taking weather readings.
They are rather free spirited, aren't they, Kapitän?
And speaking of our planes,#2 has sighted Malice 117 kilometers to our south and west.
Call alert stations if you would, Graf Spee.
My pleasure, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Not every day you see a seasick warship.
I don't know how you managed it, Graf Spee, but your hue matches the Morgana mist perfectly.
You... hrrr... are evil, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: I think that's a prerequisite for being captain, or so the crew tells me.
The crew has suggested vaudeville isn't a good career alternative for me.
Funny, the crew said the same thing during the last inspection.

Fields.DialogueText: If so... then I must believe that you are... hnnng... well on your way to Admiral...
Your crew is... hnnng... wise...
That's not... hnnng... all they said...
I'm not the one who accepted a fish sandwich from a random street vendor on the dock this morning.
This has nothing to do... hrrr... with Fischbrötchen, and you know it, Kapitän.
Look, I know the diesel we picked up is... um... sour; too sour to be fully purified. But the quartermaster said it was that or we'd be sitting there for a week waiting for a tanker.
You're the only Belle nearby right now, and your bunkers were dry. Did we really have a choice?
... Ugh, oh no, hrrrrrrrr...
Look, if it would help...
*ALARM*
Merchant distress signal to the west. Captain to the bridge.
Here, take my arm. For once you can lean on me, Schiffsdame.
I swear on all that's holy, Kapitän, that before I am done with the Versorgungsoffizier on card night, he will be destitute. Destitute, do you hear me!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, sighting to the west. I was hoping...
*ALARM*
Morgana sighted 30 degrees port. Captain to the bridge.
Can this wait until after we deal with them, Graf Spee?
Ja, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Well that was rewarding. Best pummeling we've given all cruise. If you weren't telling me otherwise, I'd swear we sank her for good.
Kapitän...
You had something you wanted to talk to me about?
No disrespect, Kapitän... but... had you ever thought to ask Cowar... Fräulein Cowardice to... surrender?
Surrender? Graf Spee, you're... serious...
Yes, Kapitän! I know as well as anyone that Morganas don't surrender, but this is Fräulein Cowardice we're talking about.
I'm not aware anyone has asked before. Maybe... maybe she might be different.
Maybe before we fired that last volley?

Fields.MenuText: I think we should continue this when I can sit down with a glass of wine... or three...
I'm a little too sober for this conversation right now.
Germany must ferment something appropriate for this topic...

Fields.DialogueText: I have just the vintage in mind, Kapitän.
I'm sure a glass of wine will help facilitate the conversation, Kapitän.
As it so happens, Kapitän, we recently stocked some truly divine wines made from the Goldriesling variety in Meissen near where I was born.
You have my full attention now. Talk to me.
Not every nation's officers are familiar with guerre de course or Handelskrieg.
I know the American admiral Alfred Mahan detested it. His book is required reading at the Academy and he wrote extensively about it.
Be that as it may, Kapitän, naval blockades and prize taking have a long, even noble, history.
Go on...
More than that, for Germany it is core to our naval strategy... and I was born to perform it. Trade war is in my blood.
I follow you so far, Graf Spee.
Kapitän, there are rules to war. One of those rules is that killing a disarmed, helpless enemy without an offer to surrender is murder.

Fields.MenuText: But isn't that what the Morganas are doing?
The Morganas aren't human.
Aren't the Morganas just killing machines?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe the Nixe just don't know the rules. Am I insane for thinking that perhaps it's time we try teaching them?
I know that better than anyone, Kapitän. Just remember... neither am I. If I can learn the rules, if I can observe ethics, isn't there a chance they can too?
Perhaps they are. Just remember... so am I. But if I can learn the rules, if I can develop my own moral compass, why can't they?
*ALARM*
Speak of the devil. Graf Spee, we'll continue this later.
It is okay, Kapitän. Duty calls. And for the record, it's Fräulein Cowardice.
@BATTLE
You lied, Kapitän!
No, Graf Spee, I bluffed. There's a difference.
You have an inscrutable poker face. That's your strength. I can't beat it. So I went the other way and feigned a better hand.
It still reeks of deceit.
Here's a question for you, Graf Spee. What is more merciful? To defeat an enemy in a rage of gunfire? Or to convince an enemy to accept bloodless defeat without firing a shot?
You're saying deceit for merciful aims isn't necessarily dishonorable?
You tell me. You're the ethicist.
It feels like a slippery slope to me.
Perhaps. And maybe it's not the noblest military strategy, but it can work.
So you're saying not to let a distaste for the less genteel arts of war limit my horizons.

Fields.MenuText: It's worth considering.
Wars are won in the mind as much as out on the battlefield.
At the very least, it's good to know in case an opponent tries to bluff when the stakes are higher.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I should re-read Von Clausewitz, Kapitän.
This is true, Kapitän. Von Clausewitz couldn't have said it better.
The better to see through the fog of war.
I'll give it more thought after we defeat Fräulein Malice. She's trying to sneak up on us again, Kapitän.
That's some mighty fine radar you're wearing there, Graf Spee.
Thank you, Kapitän.
One of these days we'll train Malice not to do that.
Train her? Hmmm...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
We're pushing the engines pretty hard.
Ja. This is a rescue mission, Kapitän. Or at least we hope it is.
We received a distress signal?
Indeed.
Understood.
@BATTLE
We've received word from the freighter who called us. They made it safely away.
Very glad to hear it.
Was it my imagination, or was Cowardice more persistent than usual today?
She certainly did seem more... inspired, Kapitän.
Inspired, eh? Well, she wasn't the only one, Graf Spee. That was some inspired dancing getting us in range to engage Morganas without needing rescue ourselves.
I told you the dolphins were training, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose evidence demands I cede that point.
Dolphins or no, that was some genius maneuvering.
It probably was foolish of me to think I could understand how a ship prepares herself for battle.

Fields.DialogueText: I try to ensure that there is method to my madness.
Thank you, Kapitän.
I think once you understand my reasoning, Kapitän, that my methods won't seem quite so perplexing.
We would have been no help to that repair ship had we also taken damage and had to withdraw. I was doing my job no more than the men in the turrets.
Hmm. Well, at least we were able to save the crew even if we couldn't save the ship. How are our passengers doing, anyway?
They're professionals, Kapitän. As would be expected of professional sailors, they are doing the Royal Navy proud.
Is the doctor finished tending to their captain yet?
I believe so. His officers have gathered in sick bay and they're discussing recent events amongst themselves.
I see. Then why don't we go join them, Graf Spee? Perhaps we can find some clues as to why Cowardice was disinclined to back down.
I thought I'd find you here in your little chapel, Graf Spee.
That's a lovely rosary you have there. Hand carved, isn't it?
You've been pensive ever since we stopped to load supplies.
Look, I wouldn't usually interfere with your personal life any more than I would with one of the crew, and I really hate interrupting prayers, but...
But I'm affecting the crew.

Fields.MenuText: Something like that.
They're worried about you, Graf Spee.
The passion of today's Nietzsche debate in the mess did kind of bring me here...

Fields.DialogueText: I will do better to keep my anxieties to myself, Kapitän.
I know, Kapitän. I'm sorry for causing them trouble.
Questioning can be contagious, Kapitän. But my anxieties spread more than others, so I understand I need to do better at controlling them.
I appreciate that, Graf Spee. Is it anything I can help with?
Kapitän, have you ever heard the phrase "it's running down my back ice cold?"
Yes, Graf Spee. Yes, I have.
I've felt like that ever since I dropped anchor yesterday. It's started me thinking... about death.
*ALARM*
Merchant distress signal offshore. Prepare to weigh anchor. Captain to the bridge.
We'll talk more, later, Graf Spee. I promise. But first we have to save some lives.
My pleasure, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
I was surprised not to find you in your chapel, Graf Spee. You don't usually come topside to get lost in thought.
I'm not sure if prayer can help me at the moment. Achtern seemed a more comfortable place for my thoughts right now.
I can't say whether I can help much if that's the case, but I'll do my best. So, a penny for your thoughts?
Even in war, a Catholic is expected to seek absolution for enemies killed. Killing the enemy, even when observing the rules of war, is still breaking a Commandment.
Hmm...
Kapitän, should I seek absolution for destroying Nixe?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know, Graf Spee. I never really thought about it. But what matters is what you think. What do you think?
I expect they're not what Moses had in mind when he walked down from Mount Sinai, but what matters is what you think. What do you think?
I'm told confession is a pretty personal matter, Graf Spee. What matters is what you think. What do you think?

Fields.DialogueText: They're intelligent. They can reason... sometimes.
They're intelligent. They can reason... sometimes.
They're intelligent. They can reason... sometimes.
No arguments.
The Commandment says, "Thou shalt not kill." Are the Nixe exempt? And if so, am I as well if, for example, you turned my guns to the human war?

Fields.MenuText: You don't ask the easy questions, do you, Graf Spee?
They don't teach us answers to these things in the Naval Academy.
I'm beginning to think the fleet needs more chaplains.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps. But if they were easy questions, I would have figured them out by now.
Until now, I suppose they did not need to.
You should give yourself more credit, Kapitän.
At least you can have some time to think about it too. As usual when it matters, the alarm will go off in a moment.
@BATTLE
Isn't the cathedral magnificent, Graf Spee? It dominates the entire skyline even from here in the harbor. To imagine that it's over half a millennium old...
I suppose. Kapitän, is there a reason you brought me up here on deck?
As a matter of fact, there is. You've been moping ever since we came here. Don't deny it.
Moping is such a strong term...
You wish you could go up there, don't you?
Of course I do, Kapitän. It's such a powerful symbol full of history and architecture. But I can't go there. So yes, I'd be lying if I didn't say I feel disappointed. Are you happy now?
Kapitän?
Not to hear that you're hurting, no. But to hear you say it, yes, I am happy. Now we can do something about it.
Do something?
See that man in a clerical collar walking up the gangplank?
A priest?
I'd like you to spend some time with Father Raming. The Versorgungsoffizier tracked him down. Said something about penance for the sour diesel we loaded a while back.
He did that... for me?
That's right. I'm told he's German. We thought you might appreciate a priest from home. It seems he's very interested in meeting you, too.
*ALARM*
Morgana reported approaching the harbor. Crew prepare to weigh anchor. Captain to the bridge.

Fields.MenuText: Let's just hope the old man doesn't get seasick.
So much for shore leave.
With luck we'll have enough crew to run the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: He's German, Kapitän! Of course he'll be fine!
I'll make short work of this one, I swear to you, Kapitän! I have things to do!
We'll send that Nixe away if I have to do it myself! I have things to do!
@BATTLE
Did you have a nice chat with Father Raming?
It was lovely, Kapitän. It was my first confession, but Father Raming was very kind despite the awkwardness for both of us.
I imagine Rome hasn't gotten around to producing guidelines for absolving a warship.
So Father told me. Still, I think I'm glad he was able to make it up as he went.
I know that feeling...
Father Raming encouraged me to be open with you. You understand me better than anyone else. I needed to be reminded of that.
Anything on your mind, then?
Many things. Do the Nixen deserve mercy? Should I seek confession for killing Nixen? Can a Nixe comprehend grace?
And?
I was born a weapon. More than that, to my chagrin the purpose Germany gave me before I came to you was to prey on the weak and flee the strong.
But I've gained grace and can weigh right from wrong myself... subject to your orders, of course.

Fields.MenuText: I'm coming to trust your instincts, Graf Spee.
I'll try never to force you to act against your principles, Graf Spee.
Just because I'm captain doesn't give me a monopoly on the right answers. I value your perspective.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate that, Kapitän.
I don't doubt that, Kapitän.
I'll do my best never to disappoint you, Kapitän.
But...
Kapitän, I want to try to change Fräulein Cowardice; to teach her grace and perhaps prevent more innocent deaths.
Maybe it's her name... or perhaps just my intuition... but I want to believe she might be persuaded.
You said it yourself - maybe the Morganas don't know the rules. Perhaps she might listen.
It's worth finding out.
@BATTLE
So, Graf Spee, what do you think?
It's... lovely, Kapitän. To see it framed and mounted; hanging from such a place of honor in the Offiziersmesse, even. I'm speechless.
You don't sound speechless to me, Graf Spee.
It's not just that this paints the cathedral in such detail, Kapitän. Father Raming tells me this was from the entire archdiocese; a gift just for me.
Even Rome is grateful for the service you Belles provide, you know. This entire region is grateful to you.
But Kapitän, I'm just doing what I was created to do. If the Morganas hadn't come, I'd be troubling everyone in service of a cause... less universal.
But the Morganas are here, and you're here, and you're saving countless lives here. It's human nature to be grateful.
Grateful? Like I am for this painting?

Fields.MenuText: Something like that. And if you're grateful, then perhaps you're more human than you think.
You must be doing something right.
They're putting their trust in you.

Fields.DialogueText: I... don't know.
Perhaps I am.
I pray that I may live up to the responsibility.
I'll think on your words, Kapitän, after we address Fräulein Malice again. She's stalking us 170 degrees to port and out about 20 kilometers.
I'm grateful for that sixth sense of yours, Graf Spee.
@BATTLE
Where did you find all these old documents, Graf Spee?
The Zahlmeister was kind enough to scour our recent ports for me. I was amazed at what he could find in bookstores and antiquities shops.
Looks like. So is all this what I think it is?
The Paris Declaration of 1856, the 1907 Hague Convention, the Geneva Conventions of 1854 and 1929, and a hundred years of other treatises and court rulings on maritime law.
I'm impressed by your tenacity over this, Graf Spee.
As I've said, Kapitän. I fight to win.

Fields.MenuText: That's the spirit!
Just don't lose sight of the war as you focus on your own battle.
Unfortunately, so do the Morganas...

Fields.DialogueText: I knew you'd approve. And speaking of winning...
Some wars are won by a single battle. Only in hindsight, though, do we know that. And speaking of battle...
Whatever the Nixen present us with, together you and I will always rise to the challenge. Right, Kapitän? And speaking of challenge...
*ALARM*
Right on cue. Shall we go discover where this battle will lead, Kapitän?
After you, Graf Spee.
@BATTLE
Will you stop running, Fräulein Cowardice!
I can keep up this pace as long as you can.
Fräulein Cowardice, why do you attack unarmed ships without warning? Why can't you order them to surrender and let the humans off before taking your prize?
I understand prize taking. You and I are not so different. But you can take your prize without resorting to murder!
I think you and I may have been born for the same purpose. If not for you Nixen coming along, Deutschland's influence might have made me into you!
Graf Spee, Plane #1 reports Morgana reinforcements approaching.

Fields.MenuText: Talk is over... for now.
The Morganas seem itching for a fight.
I'm no Belle, but I get the sense the other Morganas don't want you talking to Cowardice.

Fields.DialogueText: I understand, Kapitän.
Then I will give them one they won't forget.
I'll take that as a good sign.
Fräulein Cowardice, I'm not giving up on this.
@BATTLE
So who is this young lady?
Her name is Emily. One of the spotters noticed her in the wreckage from Fräulein Cowardice's last victim.
Is she okay?
According to the Doktor, as well as can be expected for a little girl who watched her parents plucked out of the water by a Nixe. She asked me where the monsters took her mother...

Fields.MenuText: What did you tell her?
I can only imagine what she's gone through.
That's something I'd like to know myself.

Fields.DialogueText: I changed the subject and she fell asleep not long after.
I know, Kapitän. After all this time, even we still aren't used to the screams of the captured as the Nixen retreat. And yet...
And I as well. Yet despite no good answer, she isn't giving up.
She's so brave. She hasn't even cried since she came on board. Instead she demanded a boat to go after her parents herself. The crew asked me to help calm her.
She seems the persistent type, though. I'm sure she'll ask again.
I know, Kapitän. I'd save her parents myself if I could. Maybe my entreaties to Cowardice have had some impact. Maybe her parents really are okay.
You sound like you're trying to convince yourself.
I owe it to this little girl to find out, Kapitän; her and so many others who have loved ones taken by the Nixen. If we can get them to show mercy and follow the rules of war...
I'm sure it won't be too long before we'll have another encounter with Cowardice.
*ALARM*
Nixe sighted. Consider the present engagement practice.
@BATTLE
Article 30! The duration of the daily work of prisoners of war, including the time of the journey to and from work, shall not be excessive and shall in no case exceed that permitted...
... for civil workers of the locality employed on the same work. Each prisoner shall be allowed a rest of twenty-four consecutive hours each week, preferably on Sunday.
Fräulein Cowardice, stop running! The Geneva Convention is foundation material. I just want to talk to you about your prisoners.
The humans you're taking with your prizes. Are you treating them humanely?
I'm asking about the humans under your care! You're treating them well, right? They're not... dead... are they?
Calamity's cutting this short again.

Fields.MenuText: I think you're getting through to her, though.
It looks like the Hague Convention of 1907 will have to wait until tomorrow.
Is it my imagination, or is Calamity wearing earplugs?

Fields.DialogueText: She's responding to me, at least.
I'm starting to understand a little how Fräulein Mahan feels...
I think those are tompions.
Fräulein Cowardice, I'm leaving some things for you to look at in a dinghy. Prize Law and rules for treatment of prisoners. Read them.
Read them, or I'll read them to you!
@BATTLE
Still studying, I see.
Kapitän?
Your passion over Cowardice is truly amazing, Graf Spee. It really is.
But...
... But beware the madness of Don Quixote. We're warriors, not lawyers. If push comes to shove, when I give the order, I need you to give your all. Even against Cowardice.
... Maybe especially against Cowardice.
You doubt my loyalty?
Oh, not in the slightest, Graf Spee. I just have watched how single-minded you've become since we rescued that little girl. Don't bring your uncertainties into battle with you.
I'm not uncertain, Kapitän. If anything, I feel more confident in my path than I ever have in my life.
Oh?
You have my trust, Kapitän. I give it willingly with all my heart. I'm wondering; will you trust me if I try something... unorthodox?
Unorthodox?
You're wearing that poker face of yours, Graf Spee. What are you planning?
I... I may not know until the moment of action. A lot depends on Fräulein Cowardice.

Fields.MenuText: I get the sense that you may be asking a lot. Still, I do trust you, Graf Spee. Just don't get in over your head before you ask for help.
I suppose that makes sense, but don't lose sight of the fact that I'm the captain here. I can't lead you and this crew if I don't know what to expect.
Just don't forget that this isn't just about you. Where you go, the crew and I go too.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll keep that in mind, Kapitän.
I know, Kapitän. I won't do anything that commits us before you can decide the matter.
Please, Kapitän, know that I would never place myself or the crew in danger except on your orders.
*ALARM*
That's Fräulein Cowardice... and her fleet.
Then let's go have another "talk" with her, shall we? I'm curious to see where this leads.
@BATTLE
Did you read what I left you last time?
Do you see that you can still take your prizes but also observe the law? You can blockade without bloodshed!
Can we at least talk about your prisoners? Would you consider letting the Red Cross visit them? I'd... I'd even be willing to carry their delegation...
Yes, perhaps I could come with you, weapons secured, to allow the proper authorities to address the needs of your prisoners according to the Geneva Convention.
Gauging by her speed, it appears Calamity wants in on this discussion really badly.

Fields.MenuText: I might add that she's not the only one...
If I'm right about her thoughts on the matter, I may actually be on her side this time...
This is a boondoggle, and a dangerous one at that.

Fields.DialogueText: I expected we'd have much more to discuss regardless.
Kapitän, I always planned that you'd make the final decision.
I know, Kapitän. I am willing to take a calculated risk on there being a point to all this.
Still, isn't it worth at least seeing if she agrees? If she does, the rest is just logistics, right?
Just logistics, she says...
@BATTLE
Damn these seas. The water's rough for us, much less for them. Look. That one's foundering already. We should pull it up soon...
At least Fräulein Cowardice let everyone abandon ship before she sank it. That's a first. Maybe we're getting through to her.
Maybe. It'll take hours to gather up all the lifeboats from a passenger liner, though. She also came, attacked and left. She didn't take anything.
I have a bad feeling about that...
No... not now...
Graf Spee? What is it?
Fräulein Malice...
Fräulein Malice! If you attack those lifeboats...!
Oh, Graf Spee. I wouldn't dream of it. They're tying you down, after all.
What?
Think about it. Cowardice's little concession leaves you busy as a glorified ferry at best.
And the longer it takes to relieve you of your babysitting, the longer she - and I - get to play unfettered.
Should I go my own way? You can't be in three places at once, after all... Or, I could let Cowardice do the dirty work and just take her toys... Decisions, decisions...
You did this! You twisted Cowardice!
And now you point fingers. No, Fräulein, you brought this on yourself. You're such a fine teacher! Cowardice has embraced the letter of the law... just as you wanted.
That's not... There's more to...
But I've taken up far too much of your precious time. I'll let you get back to the heroic little rescue Cowardice created just for you. Auf Wiedersehen.
... Kapitän...

Fields.MenuText: Rescue first. We'll talk after Malice's attack.
Don't let Malice get to you. You can settle the score when she comes back.
Think you can speed up the rescue process? The sooner we're ready for Malice, the better.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän. But... what makes you so sure she'll attack me, and here?
With pleas... What? But why? The rescue will keep me busy here and she wants to go where I can't stop her, correct? Why would she come back?
I can and will, with or without the threat of Fra... Malice. But what makes you confident she will return?
She knows where we are now. She thinks taking on survivors will slow us down and limit our ability to fight. And she's twisted enough to want the rescue to fail.
I can assure you, Kapitän, she will not have her way.
@BATTLE
I never thought I'd see the day when an empty supply ship was as useful as a full one.
With the survivors of the liner on their way, we can focus on the Morganas that much sooner. Well done, Graf Spee.
... Thank you, Kapitän.
Is what Malice said still bothering you?
Ja. I was aware of a saying..."The path to hell..."
"... Is paved with good intentions," hm? You know, you can read that two ways.
You tried something that didn't work as planned, Graf Spee, but at least you tried. Your heart was in the right place.
But I've made Cowardice even more dangerous than before and the situation worse, not better.
I'm not entirely sure about that.
How can you say that? After her attack on the liner...
You fought like hell to save its passengers. You showed everyone it could be done. There is another saying you might recognize. "It is part of the discipline of humility..."
"... That we must not spare our hand where it can perform service..." All right, Kapitän. I think I see your point.
Anything else I should have?

Fields.MenuText: Hope that Cowardice is having just as much trouble in this weather would be good.
Her current location would be handy...
A sharp eye and loaded guns.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I'll also hope the weather will be charitable to us.
Leave that to me.
Always, Kapitän. Always.
@BATTLE
Confession?
Yes, Kapitän. Father Raming reminded me that, in times long past and for extended voyages, when at sea, the Kapitän of a ship can act as confessor.
Um... I'm not sure what I'm supposed to do.
You just listen and help me organize my thoughts.
Isn't that what I've been doing ever since we met?
Exactly, Kapitän. You're a good counselor. That's one of the many qualities I admired about you when I chose you.
And what were the other qualities?
That would be telling, wouldn't it, Kapitän?
Anything you should confess?
... Well...
Yes?
I did agree to a game of Offiziersskat...
And you haven't taught me the rules yet. I'm ready when you are...
Allow me to fetch my deck.

Fields.MenuText: A good counselor, huh? I think this friendship will be good for the both of us.
Graf Spee might not be the only one with something to confess...
